Place-based: Evidence from Vietnam





Fast economic growth can amplify spatial inequality, especially in developing countries where movement across space is costly. In such a world, shall a government subsidize firms to enter or people to migrate out of poorer regions to increase welfare? What about a combination of them? I seek to answer these questions in the context of Vietnam. First, I document a pair of place-based and migration policies in the 2000s and show how they affect firmsâ€™ locations. I then leverage the time-varying aspect of the place-based policy to estimate a structural parameter of a dynamic model with forward-looking firms and households.






Apr 17, 2022


Nghiem Q. Huynh

title: Nghiem Q. Huynh
text:
I am fourth-year PhD student in economics at Yale University.
My research interests are trade, spatial, and development economics. My CV is here.
